about.title: About Me
about.content:
Welcome to my math blog! I am (shamim akhtar) currently a 2nd year student at Chennai Mathematical Institute, pursuing a double major in Math + CS. Although i suck at CS, i suck more at physics. This blog’s main purpose is storage for papers at CMI(quizzes, midsems, endsems, maybe other interesting problems), and just going a tad more into detail about the intricacies (why/what) involved while learning something new and how sigma mathematics is!
CMI has been, atleast academically, a stellar place - being surrounded by so many sigmas (seriously, hands down the smartest people i have ever come across) has truly been one of the moments ever - although this sometimes does put me in existential crisis, its still very fun.

  
    What got me into math?
  
  
  I just wanted to aura farm in 6th grade and read through my elder sister's math textbook (class 9,10,11) and slowly realised that it was entirely different from the trash i dealt with previously(and in the future, until 12th)


  
    Miring status
  
  
  Height - 5'7, Weight - 63 kg approx , decently muscular (mainly back and bicep) - best stat - can do 15 strict pullups, curl 15 kgs 7x per hand.
  Favorite protein source - amul rose lassi - 750 rs for 30 units


  
    Religion
  
  
  Sigma religion (chennai muslim institute)

analysis-2/index-analysis.title: Course Overview
analysis-2/index-analysis.content:
Instructor : R Srinivasan (Vasanth)
Focus: Advanced Metric Spaces and Analysis, Elementary Functional Analysis, Baire Category, Ascoli-Arzela, Stone-Weierstrass, Connectedness, Banach Spaces, Hilbert Spaces, Fourier Analysis

  
    Quiz 2
  
  
  
  
Insight :
Problem 3 is a great “first time” moment where ascoli-arzela seems to be useful - it proves the Heine-Borel theorem in one line!


  
    Midsem
  
  
  
  
Insight :
Problem A2 : Lebesgue Numbers
Problem A4 : The crux is that the map x \mapsto d(x,Tx) is continuous! (and note the domain is compact!)
Problem A5 : Just the proof of Ascoli Arzela


  
    Endsem
  
  
  
  
Insight:
Problem A7 : \int D_N(t) dt is bad!
Problem A9 : Use Cauchy Schwarz (exploit L^2)
Problem B1 : Proving surjectivity was very difficult, but “Invariance of Domain” trivialises it - which was unfortunately unknown (until topology is taught)
Problem B6 : Construct a sequence which is an approximate identity, and then use the uniform convergence fact
